pt.runtime

Class TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing

  • java.lang.Object
    • pt.runtime.AbstractTaskPool
      • pt.runtime.TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Taskpool

    public class TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing
extends AbstractTaskPool
    There is no global OneOff task queue, all tasks are placed on private queues in a round-robin fashion. Local queues are ordered such that when a thread enqueues a task into its own local queue it enqueues the task to the head of the queue. However, if a thread enqueues the task to another thread's local queue, it enqueues the task to the tail of the queue.

    If workers start to run out of work, then they steal (randomly) from another worker. [this is similar to JCilk]. This could be enhanced by favoring to steal from a worker that last succeeded to steal from. local queues are ordered such that when a thread takes a task from its owned queue it takes it from the tail (LIFO), but when it steals a task from another thread's queue, it takes it from the head (FIFO).
    Since:
    9/9/2014
    Author:
    Mostafa Mehrabi

    • Constructor Detail

      • TaskpoolLIFOWorkStealing

    • Method Detail

      • enqueueReadyTask

        protected void enqueueReadyTask(TaskID<?> taskID)
        When enqueuing a task in the WorkStealing policy, if the task is not able to be executed on any arbitrary thread, regardless of the type of enqueuing thread it will be enqueued to the privateQueue of the thread in charge of executing that task. However, if a task can be executed by arbitrary threads, then if the task is a TaskIDGroup it will be enqueued to the globalMultiTask queue, otherwise if the enqueueing thread is a Worker Thread and is not a MultiTaskWorker thread, it will enqueue the task to the head of its local queue. For other cases where the enqueuing thread is a MultiTaskWorker thread or is not a Worker Thread, the task will be enqueued to the tail of a random thread's localQueue.
        Specified by:
        enqueueReadyTask in class AbstractTaskPool
        Since:
        10/9/2014

      • workerPollNextTask

        public TaskID<?> workerPollNextTask()
        Only worker threads can call this method. This method first checks if the worker thread is a multi-task worker thread. In that case, it will check the thread's privateQueue, and if a task is found, and the attempt for executing it is successful, the task will be passed to the thread to execute.

        However, if the thread's privateQueue is empty, the method searches through the globalMultiTask queue, expands each multi-task into its sub-tasks and enqueues them as ready-to-execute tasks. However, the thread will temporarily return without having anything to execute this time.

        If the worker thread is not a multi-task worker thread, it is first attempted to poll a task from the head of that thread's localOneOffTask queue. If a task is found and the preliminary attempt for executing it is successful, that task will be passed to the thread to execute.

        However, if there are no tasks in the thread's localOneOffTask queue, the thread will try to steal a task from the tail of another thread's localOneOffTask queue. Preferably, if there is a thread from which a task has been stolen already (aka victim thread), we would like to steal from the same victim's localOneOffTask queue.

        But if there isn't any previous victims for task stealing, starting from a random thread's localOneOffTask queue, and proceeds through every thread's localOneOffTask queue (except for the current thread's own queue) and looks for a task to steal from the tail of that local queue. Once a task is found, and the preliminary attempt for executing it is successful, that task will be passed to the thread, and that localOneOffTask queue's corresponding thread will be remembered as the victim thread.

        After all these processes, if there are still no tasks found, the victim thread will be set to null and the method returns null indicating an unsuccessful attempt for polling a task.
        Specified by:
        workerPollNextTask in interface Taskpool
        Specified by:
        workerPollNextTask in class AbstractTaskPool
        Returns:
        Since:
        14/9/2014
